functions package¶

Submodules¶

functions.basic module¶

Misc. base/simple functions. These should not require import of other modules in this package to prevent circular imports.

functions.basic.ask_yes_no(prompt='', response_attempt=1)¶

Function to get the user’s yes/no response to a question.

Accepts variations of yes/y, true/t, no/n, false/f. :param prompt: the question to ask the user. :return Boolean: default is False (e.g. user hits Enter w/o typing anything else), but variations of yes or true responses will return True instead. The response attempt parameter indicates the number of attempts allowed before the function exits. This prevents the script from getting stuck in a loop.

functions.basic.check_empty(value, lower=True)¶

Checks if the value represents a null value.

functions.basic.check_value_expected_in_set(value, set1, expected=True)¶

Check if a value is present within a set and if it is expected.

functions.basic.check_value_in_two_sets(value, set1, set2)¶

Check if a value is present within two sets.

The functions returns whether it is present within: 1. only the ‘first’ set 2. only the ‘second’ set 3. ‘both’ sets 4. ‘neither’ set

functions.basic.close_files(list_of_filehandles)¶

Closes all the files in a list of open file handles. The ‘list_of_filehandles’ parameter is a list of open file handles.

functions.basic.compare_cluster_subcluster(cluster, subcluster)¶

Check if a cluster designation is part of a subcluster designation.

functions.basic.compare_sets(set1, set2)¶

Compute the intersection and differences between two sets.

functions.basic.convert_empty(input_value, format, upper=False)¶

Converts common NULL value formats.

The type of formats include: ‘empty_string’ = ‘’ ‘none_string’ = ‘none’ ‘null_string’ = ‘null’ ‘none_object’ = None ‘na_long’ = ‘not applicable’ ‘na_short’ = ‘na’ ‘n/a’ = ‘n/a’ ‘zero_string’ = ‘0’ ‘zero_num’ = 0 ‘empty_datetime_obj’ = datetime object with arbitrary date, ‘1/1/0001’

functions.basic.edit_suffix(value, option, suffix='_Draft')¶

Adds or removes the indicated suffix to an input value. The suffix is not added if the input value already has the suffix.

functions.basic.expand_path(input_path)¶

Attempts to coerce input paths in any relative format into an absolute path. :param input_path: the path to be expanded :return expanded_path: the expanded path

functions.basic.find_expression(expression, list_of_items)¶

Searches through a list of items and counts the number of items that match the regular expression.

functions.basic.get_input(prompt='')¶

Wrapper function to improve testing.

functions.basic.identify_files(path_to_folder)¶

Create a list of filenames from an indicated directory.

functions.basic.identify_nested_items(complete_list)¶

Iterate over a list of two-elemtn tuples and generate two lists.

The first list contains all tuples that are not nested in the original list. The second list contains all tuples that are nested in the original list.

functions.basic.identify_one_list_duplicates(item_list)¶

Identify duplicate items within a list.

functions.basic.identify_two_list_duplicates(item1_list, item2_list)¶

Identify duplicate items between two lists. It does not identify duplicate items within each list.

functions.basic.identify_unique_items(complete_list)¶

Iterate over a list of items and generate two lists.

The first list contains items that are unique and non-duplicated in the original list. The second list contains items that are not unique in the original list, although non-duplicated items are returned.

functions.basic.lower_case(value)¶

Return the value lowercased if it is within a specific set of values.

functions.basic.match_items(list1, list2)¶

Match values of two lists and return several results.

First, return the set of matched unique values. Second, return the set of unmatched unique values from the first list. Third, return the set of unmatched unique values from the second list. Fourth, return the set of duplicate values from the first list. Fifth, return the set of unmatched unique values from the second list.

functions.basic.parse_names_from_record_field(description)¶

Parse string of text from GenBank-formatted flat file to identify the phage name and host_genus name.

functions.basic.reformat_coordinates(left, right, current, new)¶

Converts common coordinate formats.

The type of coordinate formats include: ‘0_half_open’ = 0-based half-open intervals that is the common format

for BAM files and UCSC Browser database. This format seems to be more efficient when performing genomics computations.

‘1_closed’ = 1-based closed intervals that is the common format

for the Phamerator Database, UCSC Browser, the Ensembl genomics database, VCF files, GFF files. This format seems to be more intuitive and used for visualization.

The function assumes coordinates reflect the left and right boundaries (where the left coordinates is smaller than the right coordinate), instead of gene start and stop coordinates.

functions.basic.reformat_description(description)¶

Removes leading and trailing whitespace from text and returns this value. Then it assesses whether the description is informative or not, processes it if it is too generic (converting it to an empty value), then returning this second value.

functions.basic.reformat_strand(input_value, format, case=False)¶

Converts common strand orientation formats.

The format types include: ‘fr_long’ (‘forward’, ‘reverse’) ‘fr_short’ (‘f’, ‘r’) ‘fr_abbrev1’ (‘for’, ‘rev’) ‘fr_abbrev2’ (‘fwd’, ‘rev’) ‘tb_long’ (‘top’, ‘bottom’) ‘tb_short’ (‘t’, ‘b’) ‘wc_long’ (‘watson’, ‘crick’) ‘wc_short’ (‘w’,’c’) ‘operator’ (‘+’, ‘-‘) ‘numeric’ (1, -1).

functions.basic.split_string(string)¶

Split a string based on alphanumeric characters.

Iterates through a string, identifies the first position in which the character is a digit, and creates two strings at this position. The first string returned contains only alphabetic characters. The second string returned contains only numeric characters. If there are no numeric characters present, the second string will be empty. If there are no alphabetic characters present, the first string will be empty.

functions.basic.trim_characters(string)¶

Remove leading and trailing generic characters from a string.

functions.basic.verify_path(filepath, kind=None)¶

Verifies that a given filepath exists, and if a kind is given, it verifies that it exists as the indicated kind. :param filepath: full path to the desired file/directory. :param kind: (“file”, “dir”), corresponding with paths to be checked as either files or directories. :return Boolean: True if filepath is verified, False otherwise.

functions.flat_files module¶

Functions to interact with, use, and parse genomic data from GenBank-formatted flat files.

functions.flat_files.copy_data_to(bundle, type, flag='ticket')¶

Copy data to a ‘flat_file’ genome object.

The ‘flat_file’ attributes that should be populated need to be set to the value indicated by the ‘flag’ parameter. The ‘type’ parameter indicates the type of genome that can be used to populate the ‘flat_file’ genome object.

functions.flat_files.create_seqfeature_dictionary(seqfeature_list)¶

Create a dictionary of Biopython SeqFeature objects based on their type.

From a list of all Biopython SeqFeatures derived from a GenBank-formatted flat file, create a dictionary of SeqFeatures based on their type. Key = seqfeature type (source, tRNA, CDS, other). Value = list of features.

functions.flat_files.parse_cds_seqfeature(seqfeature, genome_id='')¶

Parse data from a Biopython CDS SeqFeature object into a Cds object.

functions.flat_files.parse_coordinates(seqfeature)¶

Parse the boundary coordinates from a GenBank-formatted flat file.

The functions takes a Biopython SeqFeature object containing data that was parsed from the feature in the flat file. Parsing these coordinates can be tricky. There can be more than one set of coordinates if it is a compound location. Also, the boundaries may not be precise; instead they may be open or fuzzy.

functions.flat_files.parse_files(file_list, id_field='organism_name')¶

Parse data from a list of flat files.

The functions returns: 1. a list of Genome objects with data parsed from each file. 2. a list of filenames that were successfully parsed. 3. a list of filenames that were not successfully parsed. .

functions.flat_files.parse_genome_data(seqrecord, filepath='', translation_table=11, phage_id_field='organism_name')¶

Parse a GenBank-formatted flat file into a Genome object.

Data from the flat file has already been parsed y Biopython SeqIO into a SeqRecord object, and data from this object is parsed into a Genome object.

functions.flat_files.parse_source_seqfeature(seqfeature, genome_id='')¶

Parses a Biopython Source SeqFeature.

functions.flat_files.parse_tmrna_seqfeature(seqfeature, genome_id='')¶

Parses a Biopython tRNA SeqFeature.

functions.flat_files.parse_trna_seqfeature(seqfeature, genome_id='')¶

Parses a Biopython tRNA SeqFeature.

functions.misc module¶

Misc. functions useful for comparing and processing genomes.

functions.misc.create_fasta_seqrecord(header, sequence_string)¶

Create a fasta-formatted Biopython SeqRecord object.

functions.misc.match_genome_by_id(bundle_obj, genome_dict, key1, key2=None)¶

Match genome object to another genome object using id. The ‘key1’ parameter provides the type of genome stored in the Bundle genome dictionary to base the match from. The ‘key2’ parameter provides the type of genome to be stored in the Bundle genome dictionary.

functions.misc.match_genomes(list_of_bundle_objects, genome_dict, key1, key2=None)¶

Match genome object to another genome object using id. The ‘key1’ parameter provides the type of genome stored in the Bundle genome dictionary to base the match from. The ‘key2’ parameter provides the type of genome to be stored in the Bundle genome dictionary.

functions.phagesdb module¶

Functions to interact with PhagesDB

functions.phagesdb.construct_phage_url(phage_name)¶

Create URL to retrieve phage-specific data from PhagesDB.

functions.phagesdb.copy_data_from(bundle, type, flag='retrieve')¶

Copy data from a ‘phagesdb’ genome object.

If a genome object stored in the Bundle object has attributes that are set to be ‘retrieved’ and auto-filled, retrieve the data from PhagesDB to complete the genome. The ‘type’ parameter indicates the type of genome that may need to be populated from PhagesDB.

functions.phagesdb.create_cluster_subcluster_sets(url='https://phagesdb.org/api/clusters/')¶

Create sets of clusters and subclusters currently in PhagesDB.

The parameter is a list, and each element is a dictionary of data pertaining to a different cluster.

functions.phagesdb.create_host_genus_set(url='https://phagesdb.org/api/host_genera/')¶

Create a set of host genera currently in PhagesDB.

The parameter is a list, and each element is a dictionary of data pertaining to a different host genus.

functions.phagesdb.parse_accession(data_dict)¶

Retrieve Accession from PhagesDB.

functions.phagesdb.parse_cluster(data_dict)¶

Retrieve Cluster from PhagesDB.

If the phage is clustered, ‘pcluster’ is a dictionary, and one key is the Cluster data (Cluster or ‘Singleton’). If for some reason no Cluster info is added at the time the genome is added to PhagesDB, ‘pcluster’ may automatically be set to NULL, which gets converted to “Unclustered” during retrieval. In Phamerator NULL means Singleton, and the long form “Unclustered” is invalid due to its character length, so this value is converted to ‘UNK’ (‘Unknown’).

functions.phagesdb.parse_fasta_data(fasta_string)¶

Parses data returned from a fasta-formatted file.

functions.phagesdb.parse_fasta_filename(data_dict)¶

Retrieve fasta filename from PhagesDB.

functions.phagesdb.parse_genome_data(data_dict)¶

Parses a dictionary of genome data retrieved from PhagesDB into a Genome object.

functions.phagesdb.parse_host_genus(data_dict)¶

Retrieve host_genus from PhagesDB.

functions.phagesdb.parse_phage_name(data_dict)¶

Retrieve Phage Name from PhagesDB.

functions.phagesdb.parse_subcluster(data_dict)¶

Retrieve Subcluster from PhagesDB.

If for some reason no cluster info is added at the time the genome is added to PhagesDB, ‘psubcluster’ may automatically be set to NULL, which gets returned as None. If the phage is a Singleton, ‘psubcluster’ is None. If the phage is clustered but not subclustered, ‘psubcluster’ is None. If the phage is clustered and subclustered, ‘psubcluster’ is a dictionary, and one key is the Subcluster data.

functions.phagesdb.retrieve_data_list(url)¶

Retrieve list of data from PhagesDB.

functions.phagesdb.retrieve_fasta_data(fastafile_url)¶

Retrieve fasta file from PhagesDB.

functions.phagesdb.retrieve_genome_data(phage_url)¶

Retrieve all data from PhagesDB for a specific phage.

functions.phamerator module¶

Functions to interact with PhameratorDB.

functions.phamerator.copy_data_from(bundle, type, flag='retain')¶

Copy data from a ‘phamerator’ genome object.

If a genome object stored in the Bundle object has attributes that are set to be ‘retained’ from Phamerator, copy any necessary data from the Phamerator genome to the new genome. The ‘type’ parameter indicates the type of genome that may need to be populated from Phamerator.

functions.phamerator.create_cds_insert_statement(cds_feature)¶

Create a CDS-level INSERT statement using data in a CDS object.

functions.phamerator.create_cds_insert_statements(list_of_features)¶

Create a collection of CDS-level INSERT statements using data in a list of CDS objects.

functions.phamerator.create_delete_statement(table, field1, data1)¶

Create MySQL DELETE statement.

functions.phamerator.create_genome_delete_statement(genome)¶

Create a genome-level DELETE statements using data in a Genome object.

functions.phamerator.create_genome_insert_statement(genome)¶

Create a genome-level INSERT statements using data in a Genome object.

functions.phamerator.create_genome_insert_statements(genome)¶

Create a collection of genome-level INSERT statements using data in a Genome object.

functions.phamerator.create_genome_update_statements(genome)¶

Create a collection of genome-level UPDATE statements using data in a Genome object.

functions.phamerator.create_phage_id_set(sql_handle)¶

Create set of phage_ids currently in PhameratorDB.

functions.phamerator.create_seq_set(sql_handle)¶

Create set of genome sequences currently in PhameratorDB.

functions.phamerator.create_update_statement(table, field1, value1, field2, value2)¶

Create MySQL UPDATE statement. When: The new value to be added is ‘singleton’ (e.g. for Cluster and Cluster2 fields), or The new value to be added is an empty value (e.g. None, “none”, etc.), the new value is set to NULL.

functions.phamerator.implement_remove_statements()¶
functions.phamerator.implement_update_statements()¶
functions.phamerator.parse_cds_data(sql_handle, column=None, phage_id_list=None, query=None)¶

Returns Cds objects containing data parsed from a Phamerator database.

functions.phamerator.parse_gene_table_data(data_dict, trans_table=11)¶

Parse a Phamerator database dictionary to create a Cds object.

functions.phamerator.parse_genome_data(sql_handle, phage_id_list=None, phage_query=None, gene_query=None, trna_query=None)¶

Returns a list of Genome objects containing data parsed from MySQL Phamerator database.

If the ‘phage_id’ parameter contains a list of at least one valid PhageID, a Genome object will be constructed only for that phage. If the ‘phage_id’ parameter is None, Genome objects for all phages in the database will be constructed. If the ‘gene_query’ parameter is not None, Cds objects for all of the phage’s CDS features in the gene table will be constructed and added to the Genome object using the provided query. If the ‘trna_query’ parameter is True, Trna objects for all of the phage’s tRNA features in the tRNA table will be constructed add added to the Genome object using the provided query.

functions.phamerator.parse_phage_table_data(data_dict, trans_table=11)¶

Parse a Phamerator database dictionary to create a Genome object.

functions.phamerator.retrieve_data(sql_handle, column=None, query=None, phage_id_list=None)¶

Retrieve genome data from Phamerator for a single genome.

The function expects a query that selects valid, specific columns from the Phage table but does not condition on a PhageID. (e.g. ‘SELECT PhageID,Cluster FROM phage’)

functions.tickets module¶

Misc. functions to manipulate tickets.

functions.tickets.compare_tickets(list_of_tickets)¶

Compare all tickets to each other to determine if there are any ticket conflicts.

functions.tickets.copy_ticket_to_genome(bundle)¶

Construct genome objects and populate them appropriately using data from import ticket. This function operates on a Bundle object instead of a Genome object because some tickets (such as ‘replace’) need to instantiate more than one Genome object.

functions.tickets.create_bundle_dict(list_of_bundle_objects)¶

Create a dictionary of Bundle objects based on their ticket type. Key = ticket type (e.g. update, add, etc.). Value = list of Bundle objects.

functions.tickets.parse_import_ticket_data(ticket, data_list, expected_size=12, id='', direction='list_to_ticket')¶

Converts import ticket data between a list and Ticket object formats. ‘ticket’ is a Ticket object. ‘data_list’ is a list. ‘expected_size’ indicates how many elements should be in the data_list. ‘direction’ indicates whether data in the list should populate a Ticket object (‘list_to_ticket’) or data in a Ticket object should populate a list (‘ticket_to_list’). The expected data structure of the data list:

  1. Import action

  2. Primary PhageID

  3. Host

  4. Cluster

  5. Subcluster

  6. Status

  7. Annotation Author

  8. Feature field

  9. Accession

  10. Annotation QC

  11. Retrieve Record

  12. Run mode

functions.tickets.parse_import_tickets(list_of_lists)¶

Parses lists of lists of data from csv file and converts to group of parsed tickets. It also returns a lost of errors for tickets that failed to be parsed.

functions.tickets.prepare_tickets(ticket_filename)¶

Parse import table into ticket objects.
